It is now too late to turn back.
You've chosen the dark shape.
Unchanging, inexorable, never closer, never farther away, the shape closes in all around you, black and fathomless as an abyss.
You realize that you never chose a story, but this story chose you.
You will never escape, you didn't escape, could not escape, must not escape.

You choose
-- the shape,

The plain stretches on for miles and miles and miles. Except for the billboard and yourself, there is nothing to be seen.
Nearby, a strange noise begins, almost imperceptible.
In the far distance, a dark shape moves slowly across the plain towards you.
Which will you pursue?
The noise, almost imperceptible, or the dark shape, moving slowly across the plain towards you?
You may take either the noise, or the shape.
It is best to take the one you haven't taken yet.
You may read about the one you didn't take, but that is another story, and it's too late now anyway. You've made your decision -- it's best not to look back.

Behind you, she goes silent.
"I don't know who he is, exactly," she says. "I don't know who anyone is anymore. He had a piece of paper over his mouth, to hide his identity." She pauses. "I think he was smiling at you."
"Why?"
"Who was the man with the paper face?" you ask.

Your room is small, but big enough for you. It has pale grey walls, white carpet, and a large, flat window looking into the night. Your bed is pushed against one wall, so you can look out the window at the sunset. There are cabinets for your clothing. Across from the bed is a TV, which you never have any use for, and a desk with a chair, which you use to write

Your mother wheels you deeper into the darkness, toward your room. A pale twilight shines in from the windows lining the hallway. You can see the grey shapes of your mother and your wheelchair, the light drifting across your skin like a faint hand.
You know that this is only an illusion, but you appreciate it all the same.  
At the end of the hallway is a beautiful mural, a landscape of rolling green hills under a starry night sky. It stretches from the floor to the ceiling, and you reach out to it every time you pass.
You roll past it, and into your bedroom.

children.text:
"Did you buy him things?"
"No," she says. There is the sound of a sigh, mournful and long-suffering. "I should have."
You watch the grass grow as your mother pushes you along.
"What else was there?" you ask.
Your mother smiles. "There was a hotel. It was nice...but too expensive for us."
"What was it like?"
"It had a pool," she says. "I saw it once. It was beautiful."
You close your eyes. You can see it clearly. Blue water. White tiles. Sparkling clean.
"What happened to it?"
"It's still there. It's a ruin now. Just like everything else."
The wind blows. The earth rumbles in time with your heart. You lean back, staring up at the sky. It is almost blinding. You find yourself squinting...the sun makes everything seem so beautiful. Light filters through your eyelids, painting patterns on your retinas.
You do not understand these patterns yet, but you know that they are special. These patterns are everywhere, if you look for them. Your fingers twitch as you stare at these undulating designs, itching to draw them, to capture their flow and incorporate it into your own art. Nothing you've ever created has been anywhere near as beautiful as this.
"Do you think God is watching us?" you ask.
"I don't know," she says. "Sometimes...I think he's forgotten about us."
You look up at the sky. It is a perfect, cloudless blue. Not a single jet contrail mars its brilliance.
"God is watching," you say.
She smiles. "I'm glad." 
You close your eyes and bask in the sun. There is silence for a time. You open your eyes when you feel a hand on your shoulder.
"They're here," she says.
You look up. A black car has pulled up onto the grass. It looks like the kind of car a businessman would drive. Its windows are dark and impenetrable. It sits there idling as if waiting for you. You see figures moving behind the glass of the car, but you cannot make out their faces.
"Who are they?" you ask.
"They tell us what's going on," she says.
A dark-suited man emerges from the car. His face is covered by a leaf of paper. You squint to see what is written on it, but at this distance you cannot see the words. Another figure appears from the backseat, a woman. She wears a suit as well. The man approaches your mother, while the woman stands back and watches.
"Are you June Watches The Westward Sun?" the man asks.
"Yes," your mother replies.
He holds out his hand, and she takes it. They shake once up and down. Then the man withdraws a folded piece of paper and hands it to her. She takes it, opens it, and reads. She frowns. Her eyebrows furrow as her eyes flicker from one line to the next. It looks like she's struggling to contain her emotions.
As she reads, the man turns his head toward you, and seems to smile from behind his paper veil. 
"You have a beautiful son," he says.
For some reason his words send shivers up your spine. You can't tell if it's because of what he said or the way he said it--or both.
Your mother hands the paper back to the man and thanks him.
He and the woman get back in the car, and you watch as it drives away.
"What did they say?" you ask.
"They want us to go on a trip."
"Where to?"
"They didn't say."
"When do we leave?"
"In three days."
"Will they come back to get us?"
"No."
"How are we getting there?"
"They want us to go on foot."
"How will we know where to go?"
"We'll follow the road signs."
"But I can't read the road signs."
"It's OK. I'll read them to you, and you'll remember."
"How far is it?"
"A long way."
"How long will it take us to get there?"
"We won't be able to make it in one day. We'll have to camp out overnight."
"Where are we going to camp?"
"I don't know yet. We'll have to find a good spot."
"What if there aren't any good spots?"
"There are ruins everywhere. We'll pick one that looks safe."
You watch as birds circle the summit of the wall. The sunlight flashes against billions of broken glass windows in the distance, making it glitter in a beautiful burst of colours.
"OK," you say.
Your mother turns your wheelchair around in a semi-circle and begins to push you in the direction of the hospital.
"Do we have to go there?" you ask.
"Yes."
"Why?"
"Because they need help."
Your mother's voice is solemn and grim as she speaks. You watch the asphalt roll by underneath your wheels.
"Why did they give you the paper?"
"It's a contract, for a job."
"What kind of job?"
"It says...I have to keep you alive."
You are quiet.
"It was my job already," she says softly.
You tilt your head back to look at her. Her face is grim as she pushes you toward the hospital. 
The familiar building looms ahead of you, rising into the sky. It is massive and white, punctured with a grid of dark, empty windows. They used to be covered in glass that reflected the sky, but it had fallen out long ago, according to your mother.
"Why would they need me to do a job?" you ask.
Your mother does not answer for a while, pushing you along, and when she does her voice is quiet but hard. "Somebody loved you enough that we were given this chance. We have to try our best."
She doesn't say anything else. You lean back in your chair, twisting your fingers around each other. You look down at your hands. Your shadow stretches out ahead of you, rippling on the road as you move. It looks just like it always had. 
You roll past the front doors of the hospital, which stand invitingly open, a dark tunnel in the harsh sunlight. You can hear the buzzing of insects from within. You've only been through those doors once, the first time you came here. You remember being carried by your mother as she ran from the darkness, stumbling over rubble and panting in fear. That was a long time ago. Since then, you've always entered the hospital through the car-park, because there are ramps leading up to all the floors.
Wheelchairs used to ride the elevators, your mother told you, sliding up to each floor with a gentle ping! But the electricity was cut off a long time ago, and now the elevator shafts lead only down, deep into the darkness, where you can feel a cold wind blowing, even on the hottest days. You do not like to go near them-- often, you hear strange noises coming from down there, sometimes screams or sobs or horrible wet chattering sounds, or sometimes just an unintelligible babble of voices that sends shivers down your spine.
But the car-park is bright and cheery in comparison. The familiar concrete structure pans into view as your mother pushes you along. You reach the top of the slope that leads to the entrance of the car-park. Your mother turns you so you're facing forward.
"Ready?" she asks.
You grip the edges of your seat and nod.
She gives you a little push and off you go. You skim down the slope, the car-park growing larger as you speed toward it. Your mother runs after you, her long legs easily keeping pace.
You reach the bottom, skidding to a halt on the hot concrete. You lean back, testing your brakes, which sizzle slightly as they stop the chair.
"Again?" you ask.
You hear her laugh as she catches up with you, her hand gently stroking your hair.
You love going down slopes.
You go two more times, and then your mother pushes you up through the car-park to the entrance of the 3rd floor of the hospital. The once-automatic doors are permanently open, revealing a long hallway with a linoleum floor. There are weeds growing from the cracks. The walls are bare and stained, and the fluorescent lights above you are covered with cobwebs. The hallways and rooms on this floor have not been illuminated in years, but you don't need light to see. You know every inch of this place.
To the left is what was once the cafeteria, although now it contains only a few scattered, rotting tables and chairs, and what was once the cafeteria staff's break room, although now it too is abandoned. You know this, because you've been here countless times, although always with your mother at your side.
You and your mother live on the 3rd floor of the hospital, now, because it was the safest place you could find. The upper floors of the hospital have significant damage from shrapnel and wind, and are almost impossible to live in, and many parts of the lower floors are flooded with several feet of water from broken pipes.
Far above you is the roof. You've never been up there, but you know that's where your mother goes to work every day. She says she recycles waste to produce energy for the building, which powers an offline server in one of the hospital's datacentres, storing research data and what remains of the internet. You don't know exactly what that means, but you know she wants you to be safe, so you trust her.
Your mother is special. You're not sure how, but she knows things others don't. Like how to tell what season it is, just from looking at the sky. She knows where you should go to find food, even in this ruined world. Other than the food she scavenges, you and your mother survive off of cafeteria food, which hasn't gone bad yet thanks to its packaging.
It was a nice place to visit. Sometimes...I used to go there with your father."

They all worked, ticking away with big golden hands."
"Why don't they work now?"
"The tower doesn't exist anymore. The city doesn't exist anymore. Now, the world works with a different logic."
You hold her hand as she pushes you along the broken road. Passing a metal mount for traffic lights, you see that the metal pole is all twisted, like a dry riverbed. There are flowers growing atop it, orange and purple oxalis. They are perfectly

It was a very happy place. It was always busy, people walking in and out all day long. Everybody was nice to each other, and the store owners gave away lots of free things to good customers. I was a salesgirl at a jewelry shop. We sold lots of jewelry. I used to wear beautiful necklaces and rings all the time. Everybody thought I was very rich, but I wasn't. I was just a salesgirl."
You reach the bottom of the ramp.

"What was what like?" she asks, finally.
"Outside the walls. What was it like?"

children.text:
"But there's grass outside," you point out, and she laughs.
"There used to be nothing."
A few moments later, she says, "We're going to be picking someone up here soon."
You emerge into an empty plain of asphalt. Nearby, a creosote bush peeks from a crack in the pavement. The sun is a dazzling disc far above you. There's another billboard off to the side, half-fallen. On it, a beautiful woman smiles at you, her lips painted vivid red. A pink banner running below reads: SUNSET TERRACE. COME TO US FOR ALL OF YOUR SHOPPING NEEDS. There is a shadow directly beneath the sign.
"Sometimes the shadows move," you say out loud. "But the sun does not."
"That's right."
There is a rumble, distant but deep, like the shifting of the earth. You turn and look at your mother. Her eyes are closed, and she hugs you close. You can feel her heart pounding in her chest. Then, there is a second rumble, this one much closer, rocking you in place. Your mother looks up, fear on her face.
"What was that?"
She kisses you softly on the forehead. Her lips are warm.
"Nothing," she says. "Let's go."
You turn and look in the direction of the rumble. A black plume of smoke billows up into the air, far in the distance. Something has happened far away, but the concrete walls hide it from view.
She pushes your chair along the broken asphalt. The wheels roll smoothly again, as if the cracks were not there.
You lean back in your chair. The wind ruffles your hair.
You pass the shadow of the billboard, still wearing its painted smile. You cannot read the words now, but you can picture them clearly in your head:
COME TO US FOR ALL OF YOUR SHOPPING NEEDS.

There is a sudden rumble of thunder, and you turn your head to look up into the cloudless sky. A bolt of lightning strikes the ground not far away, making you jump. The lightning is white-hot, but it doesn't burn the grass. How is that possible? The thunder drives the birds mad, and they shriek at the sudden, violent presence in the air.
"Why is the sky blue?" you ask.

children.text:
...a hospital. Dilapidated and abandoned, overrun by vegetation. You are sitting in an old wheelchair. Your mother is pushing you through the long hallway. All around you are the sounds of vegetation chewing through metal and brick. There is a rusted gurney covered in vines next to a ruptured water tank. A heavy valve has fallen from the ceiling and crushed a mattress. Your mother pushes you through another door, into bright sunlight. You squint, and the light is strained into beautiful, drifting patterns. You are in a car-park. High walls surround this little pocket of the world, keeping the outside out. You can see trees and bushes growing from every crack in the wall. They are slowly taking back what is theirs. Your mother pushes you along the car-park, the wheelchair's wheels squeaking pleasantly. You roll through alternating zones of sunlight and shadow. You pass a parking attendant's booth with the windows all blown out and vines covering the interior. You can hear something inside, snuffling through the undergrowth. There's a sudden screech and a large black bird takes off from the booth, soaring over your head to perch on a wall. You shiver pleasantly at its beauty. Your mother pushes you along the path. There is grass underfoot. You reach the edge of the car-park and find yourself at the bottom of a massive parking ramp. The wall borders the edge of the car park and curves away to either side, so that you cannot see beyond it. It's buildings all the way down. You can see only a few feet above you because of the roof, but your imagination fills in the rest: an endless expanse of concrete and asphalt. Right in front of you is a yellow line painted along the edge of the road. There are countless others, radiating outwards like the arms of a galaxy. You turn your head and see a yellow line running parallel just a few meters away. Beyond that, another one, and another one.
"What were the lines for?" you ask your mother.
"They told people where to park their cars," she says. "But not anymore."
There's a broken sign lying on the ground. You can just make out the faded white letters painted on a dark blue background. PARKING RAMP: 2-4T rupees.
"What's 'rupee'?" you ask.
"It was the money people used before," your mother says. "Nobody uses it anymore."
You turn and look back at the wall, curving away past the limits of your eyes. The world is nothing but wall, forever.
"Why did they need so much wall?"
"There was nothing outside it," your mother says. "Just empty air. That's why."

Eventually, you come to the gates of a fair city within a walled plain. The letters G-A-L-A-D-I-E are written in white neon letters above the gate.
Lightning crashes and booms from

Bring a change.

You bring the stallion to a stop. "That one's easy," you say. "Can I make the world better for them?"
"That's up to you."
You turn back to your goal and drive the stallion towards it, as fast as the horse can gallop.

As you ride, more whispers of the dead are carried to your ear by the wind:

What a strange dream.

Will this one not break?

We want what all dreams desire.

We will outlive the dying sun.

The maddening sky flashes with the lightning of a million dreams.
"I'm going too fast," you say. "It's all a blur to me."
The wind carries no whispers to your ear for a time. Then, at last...

The Insider circles the stallion around the tower a time or two. The horse is made for riding, not exploring, so he's clearly enjoying the opportunity. The horse turns itself off as if by magic, and the two of you dismount. The Insider turns to you, and offers his hand once more.
The dark tower looms over the two of you. You have no idea what lies inside.

"What do you hear?"
"Nothing."
"You see? This is what I mean."
You nod and listen again. What's there is silence, broken occasionally by the sound of the stallion's metal hooves against the ground.

When you feel you've been riding for years, the Insider brings the horse to a stop in front of a vast, obsidian tower. It's completely featureless, except for a single door, the color of midnight.

"What about my things?"
"You mean all your prisms and candles? There is no need. We will pluck the forms we need out of the ether."
You pause, dazzled by the prospect. "When do we leave?"
"Now."
You stare at him, as if paralyzed. "But I..."
He smiles. "If you want, you can leave a message for your friends. They always worry, you know."
You can't remember much, but you remember knowing that all your friends are dead. But so are you, and you're here.
Your eyes drift to the words on the billboard again: ARCADIA Found within the ashes of the old world.
And so you have been coming here for years. The hooded man waits for you. The man is everything to you now. He is your father, your mother, your teacher, your master. You know you love him, in a way. But do the dead have feelings? A concept, bound by words. The only real thing for you is the turning of the page, the meeting of one chapter with another.
"I'm ready," you say. "Let's go."
The Insider smiles, and smoothly mounts his stallion. He offers you a hand, which you grab hold of. He draws you onto the machine as if you weigh nothing. You sit in front of him, and he locks an arm around you. The mechanical stallion has a joystick and several levers in place of reigns. The Insider wraps your fingers around the joystick.
He pulls one of the levers, and the horse gallops forward. You feel the wind in your hair, like you're flying. The ground's a long way down, but the hooded man will not let you fall. You hear a mournful, low horn somewhere behind you.
"Do they always cry?" you ask.
"Always. It breaks their hearts each time you leave."
You nod. "I'll come back to them."
"You always do."
"But then I leave again."
"Ah, but that's the joy of it. You only return once they've long given up hope."
The machine is simple to operate. The stallion goes where you push the joystick, and stops when you pull the levers. The Insider handles the buttons that make it roll or vibrate, somehow.
You ride for a time across the ash-colored landscape, each second stretching to an eternity. The wind beats at your face, carrying with it the scents of a million dreams. If you listen close enough, you can hear the ghosts of all those who went here before you.
"They whisper to you, don't they?" says the Insider. "The wind carries their words to your ear. Listen well. They're the lessons of the dead."
"What are they saying?" you ask.
"Listen."
You listen.

But something else takes their place.
You cannot describe it.
It is just there, because it is.
Something. Nothing. What does it matter?
Something fills you then. A feeling so strong, so present that it's like reality has doubled down on itself. And yet, there's nothing but that feeling. Total reality, like the inside of a crystal ball.

"Developer?" you say.
"I'm about as developed as I'm ever going to get," Meliodas replies.
A door appears in the wall of chains, opening into a hallway. 
Light shines from the hallway, bright and searing. You shield your eyes, unable to look at it directly. When you're able to look again, you see what seems to be the interior of a city. People in decadent dresses stroll through the marketplace, stopping to look at jewelry displayed on little podiums. Two women pass each other, one with long, curly black hair, the other with light brown hair and a ponytail. They stop and laugh, talking about different men in their lives. Realtors walk around, offering people houses and mansions and revealing the astonishing low starting prices. A trio of soldiers marches down the street, intimidating any would-be thieves or thugs. This all happens in rapid succession, a blur of color moving too fast for you to take it all in. Yet, all of these people, these humans, move with a certain grace, a certain pleasant aura that makes you want to be in their company.

You shake your head. "I still have work to do."
"I see. Well, don't let me distract you."
He mounts his steed once more. You realize you don't want him to leave. This place feels lonely without him.
"You have to go?" you ask.
He smiles. "I don't. But you wanted to be alone."
You shake your head and grab his wrist, dragging him off the horse. The Insider offers no resistance whatsoever. You stare into his hood, but the shadows conceal his face. His arm is thin but strong. He could kill you in an instant, if he wanted to.
"Who are you?" you ask, desperation in your voice. "What do you want from me?"
"I thought I had made myself clear," the Insider says softly. His hooded face is mere inches away from yours. "I am the Insider, a traveler of worlds. Worlds of the present, and worlds of the past. I am no slave to time."
"That's not clear at all."
He laughs. It's a cold, empty sound, like the wind blowing through the cracks in a grave.
"Listen, little one. I could tell you many things, fascinating things. About the Riddle of the Sphinx. About how the pyramids were really built. About how Archimedes set a ship on fire using only the sun's rays. About how the end of humanity is predicted in just 20 years by a computer built with Artificial Intelligence. But none of that is important."
"Why not?"
"Because you wouldn't understand."
"Try me," you growl. The Insider laughs again, but says nothing, and slowly withdraws his arm from your grip. His eyes never leave your face.
"If you're ever feeling lonely, I'll be here."
With those words, the billboard and the plain, shifting sands, endless sky, strange noises, and black shapes all fade to nothing.

children.text:
You hear the sound of hooves in the dust.
A man rides out of the wilderness on a golden stallion of whirring clockwork. He wears hooded robes, of an ancient style not seen for hundreds of years. As he arrives, he smiles.
"Ah, the wasteland. Such a bleak place. But it has its charms, doesn't it?"
"Is that your home, out there?"
The hooded man laughs. "My home is everywhere, and my home is nowhere."
"What are you doing here?"
"I came to welcome you to the dream. Or should I say, the recurring dream."
"I've been here before?"
The hooded man laughs once more. "But, my dear boy, you're here every night! How else could it be?"
You look around once more. Everything is so familiar, yet strangely different. "Does everything change, every time?"
"Usually. But some things are consistent. You are consistent. I'm consistent."
"What's it all about, then?"
The hooded man dismounts from his steed. He pets its metallic flanks tenderly, smiling. "It's about you. It's about me. It's about all of us, really."
"But what is it?"
"This? A dream. None of what you see is real. But neither are you. Not really."
The hooded man stares southwards, at the wasteland. "Sometimes, I ride. I ride for days. All I need is food and water for the trip, and the world is mine."
"What's there to see?"
The hooded man turns, staring at you. His eyes are black as midnight, shining with a dark fire. "Everything," he says simply, smiling once more. "Shall we go? Just you and me?"
"Who are you?"
"A traveler of worlds. A seer of sights. A warrior of myths and a mage of dreams. They call me the Insider, but that's not really my name."
"What is it, then?"
He smiles enigmatically. "Why don't you venture deeper into the dream and discover it for yourself?"
The Insider turns, then, and stares at you.
"What do you say? Shall we go?"
With that, he offers you his hand.
Will you accept the Insider's offer, and venture further into the dream?

text_attributes.child_preview: You walk up to it and peer inside through the walls of glass.

children.text: You can hear the growing hum as you grow closer to the source of the noise.

You realize, suddenly, that there is no sound here. No sound at all. It's as quiet as the eye of a storm.
You walk on soft carpeting that muffles your footsteps. There are doors every few yards, leading into little rooms with chairs situated in front of screens. The whole place seems to be designed with people sitting and watching something in mind. But nothing happens here. There are no people here.

Still, for some reason, it makes you happy. You feel warmth inside your chest.
You continue walking down the long hallways, observing more and more endless rows of lights, flickering in sequence.

And yet there is something about the place, something familiar in this place of strange lights and empty halls.
The odd familiarity, the strangeness of it all makes you feel as though you have come home.
You are strangely calm.
There is a sense of peace that fills your soul with its presence.
Overhead, the sky is black. You can see nothing of what created this apparition you now stare at.

The light is painful to look at. You only stare at it when you are forced to, looking away as your gaze bores through its powerful glow.
The building seems to go on forever, infinitely extending in all directions, row after row of lights stretching off into the void.
It is a strange sight, and your eyes burn with the effort of staring into infinity.

text_attributes.child_preview: You only stare at it when you are forced to

children.text:
It reminds you of a hangar filled with light.
You walk toward the building, feeling its brightness warm your face. You can feel your hands and feet begin to tingle in the light. You realize it must be some kind of vision; no real place could be so utterly bright as this place is.

Inside, you see a half dozen or so people moving around.
They spot you as you walk through the front doors of the structure. You walk up to the front desk, to find a man wearing a uniform looking at you. "Welcome to the Hotel Arcadia," he says, without looking up from his computer.
You stare blankly ahead, not knowing what to say.
It reminds you of a structure you saw once on the television, a long time ago. It was a place where people went to buy things.

Behind the glass, you can see hundreds of beautiful automatons, all identical, with porcelain skin and long golden hair that flows down their backs. They are dressed in togas and tunics of flowing, bright colours. Each one holds a torch that sends its smoke up through holes in the ceiling. You can see machinery behind the glass walls, pumping the bellows that keep the torches alight.
At first, the structure looks like a mirage, but as you close in, it resolves itself into a low, long building with glass walls, lit from within.
They seem so near that you feel like you could reach out and touch them, pluck them from the sky and hold them in your hands like cosmic jewels.
As you get closer, the point of light grows and divides into numerous points, forming a pattern of great complexity.

The light burns white and blinding as you get closer, a bright beacon in the midst of the endless night.
You are very tired. Sleep feels so close, so easy to reach out and touch. Your feet drag on the road behind you. You stumble occasionally, but keep walking. The light is hot against your skin as you walk toward it, like a powerful lamp in the darkness. You can feel its heat burning into your face.

The closer you get, the more clearly you can tell that it is not Arcadia. It is a campfire, burning low in the centre of the roadway.
You stop some distance away, watching the shadows dance on the ruined landscape. A voice from the darkness says something to you in a language that you do not know. You hear a sound like laughter, and then more voices join in.

You walk up the isles of burnt cars in its driveway, past piles of ash that had once been human bodies. You hear the wood and plaster cracking as the fire eats away its supports.
You keep walking.
You're almost to the door, and there is nothing to stop you from going inside.
And that's when you realize that your shadow has gone.

One of its walls has been torn off, leaving a gaping hole beneath the roof. You see a garden of dark purple flowers, their petals mangled and laying torn on the ground. You keep walking. You see a pond, glassy and still, reflecting the flickering

The house stands alone against the fields, without even the comfort of another building to stand by its side.
The house is on fire.
Maybe it always was, and the fire just never went out.
There are figures moving on the porch. They're moving in a crowd, wandering back and forth, around and around the fire. They don't look like people you recognize. They don't look like anyone you've ever seen.
Whatever

All around it, stalks of charred corn are still smoking.
The mansion is on a low hill, overlooking the blackened fields. In the distance, you can see a forest rising up, black and twisted, like the ravaged corpse of a great tree.
The barn is on fire, too. Sentinels stand vigil over the bodies of dead horses. Their harnesses are still on, as if they were put out to pasture moments before the fire broke out.
There are more

The porch is painted deep green, a color of such striking beauty that it almost takes your breath away. Its pillars look to be made of stained marble. It looks like something out of a dream.
You know this house; you've been dreaming of it for months now. You feel almost as if you've been here before.
You stand at the base of the porch for a long time, just watching it burn.

Your shadow twirls a gun in its hands, and aims it at the things in the corn.
You keep walking.
The light is coming from a burning house. It's a huge mansion, with white columns and fancy wrought-ironwork. Its porches are devoid of furniture, and empty windows stare out at you like blind eyes.

You see a light in the distance, flickering ahead of you. Maybe Arcadia is there after all, you think to yourself. You walk for what feels like hours, growing ever closer to the light. Your shadow keeps pace with you, out upon the black and white landscape. It looks almost like a child, playing some game by itself.

You keep walking.
The sun sets, and the night sky is illuminated by a thousand eyes.
The stars shine brilliantly overhead. You remember how much they used to mean to you, before everything changed. The moon is a dull silver penny in the sky. It casts a pale light over the ruined world around you.
If you look closely at the cornfields, you can see dim shapes moving in the dark.
You try not to look at them too often.

Then, in front of you, the road splits in two.
The road on the right runs up a hill, to the wreckage of a gas station. The one on the left runs out over the blackened earth, and then down, into a cracked, dry riverbed. The plane of concrete stretches out beyond where you can see, toward a horizon you can't quite make out.
You are not alone.
*
You can go home again, you know. You

The letters are chipped and faded, the paint almost completely worn away.
You keep walking.
After a while, the road begins to rise. Blackened trees line either side, branches grasping for a nonexistent sky. The sky is filled with spinning black dust, as if the dome has shattered and scattered its remains beyond the horizon. You hear the bitter wind howl across the plains.

Maybe it is.
You press on. You keep walking and walking.
You walk for time out of mind, for days and for years, aeons of walking, stumbling, hurting. You walk until every muscle in your body aches. You walk as the last of your water trickles out of your canteen, until your throat is parched and cracked. Your mouth tastes like dry, dry paper. You press on. You walk through tortured dreams that whisper through your mind

Up close, you can see that it is filled almost to the brim with rainwater.
You drink deeply from it, and then wash your face. The water feels cold and good against your skin. You fill your canteen again, and put the cap on. It leaks.
You keep walking.
The road abruptly ends. It stretches out impossibly far in front of you; it seems like you've been walking for a million miles. It ends in a blackened field.

You have no idea what it means, but it seems right.
Constructed in a rabbit warren of underground bunkers, Arcadia is a realm of pure white light, utterly unlike the world above. It is a world of stark, pragmatic contrast.

No, you don't think.
Your feet keep walking, following the shimmering asphalt. The sun, a small dot of white light filtered through a thin layer of ash, sets behind the clouds. You keep walking. The wind picks up and whistles through your hair. You remember: I'm never going to see you again.
HOME SWEET HOME it says, in letters two feet high.

You don't know why, but the sight of them makes you sad.
You keep walking.
You walk for what feels like years, through the endless black and white landscape. The road levels out, straightening out into a swath that runs through a vast field where nothing grows. You think to yourself: It looks so much like a runway. You walk past a toppled water tower, painted in peeling blue letters. You stop and look at it.

text_attributes.child_preview: The sight of them makes you sad.

children.text:
It looks like a battlefield.
You blink, suddenly remembering the smell of sulfur, and the sizzle as the kernels burst into flames. The humvee patrols that drove through the fields, their big engines crushing the corn under their weight... You can remember being back in high school, staring out the window on a rainy day and looking at all those neat rows of corn...
A shiver goes down your spine.
Off in the distance, you spot a fallen fencepost.

You begin to pick up a strange, muffled noise in the air. At first, you think it's the skeletons of the corn whispering to you, haunted by all the ghosts of the people they once grew to feed. But... it's too regular. And rhythmic. And not quite in synch with the wind.

As you approach, you can see that the billboard is gigantic, stretching thousands of feet into the sky. It's not made of wood at all, but

It has a huge main picture. It shows an enormous, bearded man, larger than life, one arm around the watchful wing of a Titan, the other holding a sword shining with heaven's light. He wears a long, flowing white beard, and is wearing golden armor. You cannot see his eyes, for he is staring off into the distance. Beneath the picture, someone has written, in large letters, the words 'HELP ME'.
In smaller letters, underneath his,

You can hear the wind moving through them. They make a creaking noise, like a noisy crowd of people whispering.
As you march down the endless road, you think you can see something in the sky ahead of you. A billboard of some kind, about five miles away.
It's larger than the last one.
The road leads past a vast expanse of blackened cornfields. The stalks have been burnt away, leaving only blackened skeletons; their metal irrigation systems thrust uselessly up into the sky.
The black line runs straight for miles ahead of you, bending neither left nor right. It just goes on, through the vast expanse of nothingness.
You know how to aim with both eyes open, and how to keep your hands from shaking as you pull the trigger.

text_attributes.child_preview: how to aim with both eyes open

children.text:
You don't want to go that way.
On either side of the road stand tall statues, looming over the endless fields of ash and poison

text_attributes.child_preview: You don't want to go that way.

children.text:
You can go forward and investigate, or turn back and head down the road.
It is your choice.
"Hello?" you call out.
Your voice is lost in the vast expanse of the barren, burnt landscape. There is no one to hear you but the wind
A sign reads: The Lord Is With You Always.

You keep walking.
The asphalt begins to crumble, giving way to soft ash that sinks down like quicksand. The road is shrinking into the ground, and you are tired.

Its eyes are hollow sockets, its face a smeared and ruined palimpsest of decay.
You touch the revolver at your hip.
The wind blows, and hear a long, howling moan that pierces the very depths of your soul, cutting to your core, laying bare your fears. You feel an icy hand close around your heart.
You do not fear it. You know that in these empty places, death is a companion, and far kinder than life.
You know that it is just the darkness inside of you, taking form.

The veil of darkness seems to have eyes, and they are watching you. You cannot look away.
At last, you come to another road. A weathered sign post stands on it, pointing one way to ARCADIA and the other to MINERAL POINT 23 MILES. The veiled shadow still hangs there in the night sky behind you, dancing upon the darkness.

You start to scream.
You want to plunge your hands into its shroud, to tear the fabric open. You want to see its face. But suddenly, you stop. You recognize the figure. You know what you see here.
The figure looks down at you with empty sockets, where once eyes had been.
You raise your hand toward it, as if to sum up courage enough to touch it.

You try to turn away.
But you know that you are not alone.
The cracked lips of the figure part, and it speaks with a voice that is hollow, monotonous, metallic.
And yet you hear every word, no matter how faint it is.
"You are not alone," it says. "None of us can be alone here, for we are all still connected."

It stares down at you, eyeless, its face a featureless smooth white blankness.
You stumble backward as it looks down at you.
Its face is a pallid mask carved from dry bone, stained-black tears running down its cheeks to its jaw, where they drip off into nothing.

Its face is covered by a black, featureless mask carved from wood. It stares down at you, sockets burning with a hungry flame, as a crown of coils surround its head like a demon god.
It opens its mouth.
A voice like the scraping of metal on metal shrieks out, shattering your mind.
"Come to me," it says.
You fall to your knees, mouthing a prayer to whatever God will listen.

"Then plug yourself in."
You tear your eyes away from it, staring down at the floor. It's cracked and broken, incapable of holding any weight. You feel as if you'll fall through it at any moment. Still, you must be standing on something, some sort of foundation. For if you stand on nothing but air, then surely you will fall...
"Do not be afraid," says the shadow. "All you need do is take one step forward."

The wind stirs the ash on the road, drawing a slow spiral between you and the shadow.
"Would you like to see your father again?"
You nod again.

"Then," says the figure, in a voice like the scraping of metal and nails on a chalkboard. "Come hither."
You take a step forward, then another, your legs moving of their own accord. You find yourself wading through the ash, toward the shadow. You close your eyes, then open them again as you draw closer. The darkness seems to grow thicker and deeper as you approach it.
A light breeze blows through your hair.

"I need you to go down into the darkness. There is a place where creeks flow. They trickle together, forming rivulets. These rivulets flow together, becoming streams. The streams flow together, becoming rivers. The rivers flow together, flowing into the sea."
The voice takes a deep breath. "But there is one stream you must cross. One single stream that flows alone. There, you will find your mother again."

"Good. I'm glad we could come to an understanding. Now, I'm going to need you to get on your knees. Can you do that for me?"
Again, you nod. As you drop to your knees, the concrete pierces through your pants and bites into your kneecaps. You wince, but do not cry out.
"You must find my name. Hidden in these books are the names of the damned. Find my name, and you can buy back your soul. Do you accept?"

The figure opens its mouth, but no words come out. You can hear the hiss of the electrical current running through its body.
You look at it, prepared for an order.
"I want you to go to your house. There are things that you must find there."
You begin to shake your head violently. "No! That house is gone! The fire burned it down!"
With a sharp crack, an arm moves from the figure, sliding across the pole.

"You will go back to that place you call home. You have retrieved the item I asked for, I trust?"
You nod, reaching into your pocket and pulling out the USB key. You hold it out, letting it dangle from your fingertips.
The shadow reaches out with its right hand, and you jump as electricity rushes through you again.

The figure pulls a small, white card from its pocket, covered on both sides with glowing green characters that shift and writhe across the surface like serpents.
You take it from its hand, and the wires loosen their grip immediately as they detect your obedience. As you fall to your knees, gasping for air, the figure points to the glowing green letters on the card. "Take this to room 666 in the ██████ Hotel,"

"You are a creative writer, are you not?"
Another nod.
"Then I will leave it to you to work out the details. Goodbye."
You stare into your own eyes, transfixed, as the figure reaches up and tears its hood off with a single vicious yank. You see your face contort in pain, as the world fades away to black...

You stare into the void beneath the shadow's hood. You cannot see its face, but when it speaks again, you know you are listening to your own voice. "Follow my instructions and you will see her again."
You nod, still unable to speak through the choking stranglehold of electricity.

"Don't struggle," the figure hisses. "It's for your own good."
With a start, you find that you can move again, though now you're standing right in front of the electrical effigy. It reaches out with its right hand, long fingernails carved from bone digging into your shoulder.

Electricity surges through your veins, and your heart flutters in your chest. Your eyes roll up into the back of your head, and you collapse onto the floor.
You have a vague feeling of fingers prodding at your neck, then the cold press of steel against your flesh. You wake up minutes later to find that the figure is gone, and the wires have unwound themselves from around your throat.
"This world is only made of our memories," the specter whispers. "I'm going to give you a choice. I can show you your old home, or your new home. Think carefully about where you want to go."

The shadow reaches out towards you.
"What... do you want?"
"Your soul."
You stare at it in confusion. "I don't have a soul. I'm undead."
The wraith's hand pauses in mid-air, before twisting its fingers into a savage snarl. Its face twists into a mask of rage as it snarls down at you. "Do not mock me, worm! I can see your soul, plain as day. Look!"
One of the wires snakes up to your face, and you feel its burning contact on your cheek.

The wraith waves you closer. "Come here."
You struggle to walk forward, as if wading through knee-deep water, struggling against a torrent of invisible hands that push you back. You force your legs to move, and the wires hiss with electricity as you step into their field, wrapping themselves around your throat like a boa constrictor.

The figure seems to grin. "Then you must do what I say."
You nod again.

A smile cracks across the face of the shadow, revealing a perfect set of pearly white teeth. "Then hold on to me, and let's ride into the storm."
Next to the shadow sits a long, wooden bicycle, its frame decayed and ancient. A wicker basket rests on the front, half-filled with a blanket of ash. You look up at the figure, staring into its shrouded face for any hint of mercy or comfort.

You stare at it, transfixed.
The sun hangs silently in the sky. Then, the shadow speaks.
"Do you want to see your mother again?"
You open your mouth to speak, but find no words will come out. You simply nod.

The eyes are hollowed out pits, bottomless black holes that threaten to swallow your very soul. You feel the world slipping away beneath you, the darkness growing up from under your feet and reaching for you with cool, spectral fingers—
  

A sharp burst of static comes from the radio, making you cry out in fear. "Do you copy?" a voice says.

"Who are you?" it asks.
You can only stare as the electricity arcs along its skin, contorting its body into a dance of seizure.
, plugging into the wall socket behind it. An iridescent halo surrounds its head, flickering in time to the electric current that crackles through its hair.

Its sheer presence is enough to make you want to scream.
You know who it is. You recognize the figure beneath the shroud.
You stare at the tortured figure that hangs before you. Its face is lost in darkness, hidden behind a veil of shadows.

Its sex is indeterminable beneath the rags it's clothed in, its face concealed by a murky hood. It's hands are outstretched in eternal pain, the nails driven into the palms oozing a stagnant pool of red. You stare up at it in terror and awe.
The shrouded figure seems to look down at you from hollow eye-holes, but it shows no signs of life.
, snaking up behind it, leading to a jagged hole in the sky.

A thick tangle of electrical wires hang from its arms, wound densely around its wrists, like the spines of a hundred snakes bundling together into a poisonous rope. Bundles of wires run up its front, around its shoulders, and down its back

The figure makes no sound but the faint rustle of cloth as it twists in a non-existent wind.
The shrouded crucified figure stares sightlessly ahead. It does not blink. It does not breathe. It is dead and yet somehow still alive. It takes you a moment to realize that it is waiting for you to do something.

The dead man stares down at you, eyes glinting malevolently from within the black holes of its hood. Its lips part slightly, revealing a bright, blood red smile.
"You are not alone," it whispers in a voice that seems to come from everywhere.
It takes a moment for you to find your voice.
"W-who are you?"
"We are many,"

Its face is a pallid, perfect mask, cold and white like marble. It looks down upon you with empty eyes, soulless and cold, dark pits that suck you in and refuse to let go.
You stumble backward, your heart pounding in your ears. There is something unearthly about this figure. Unreal. Alien. Your skin grows cold as you stare at the crucified phantom. This can't be real. This isn't real. This isn't real...

Its face is no face at all, but a gaping hole of darkness—a vortex that screams. A shadow with three red eyes, set like embers into the depths of its hood.
You raise your gun, trying to steady your shaking hands.
The creature ignores it.

Only eyes can be seen, two burning, golden pinpoints of light that stare down at you.
You look into those twin suns, unable to turn away. You are transfixed by them. You cannot understand why they stare at you so hungrily when such a feast as this lies all around, the land beneath your feet charred black and white with the bones of burnt offerings.

Its face is concealed within its depths, hidden from you in the dark of the veil.
You can glimpse nothing but the faint shimmer of eyes, white with a thousand tiny pupils lining both sides of the holes that conceal its gaze. It looks down upon you, an omnipresent watcher in the darkness.

As you grow closer, the shadow grows more solid. More real. It looms over you now, a specter of death on a barren plain of ash. You stare up at it, stifling a shriek.
The figure stares down upon you, shrouded in darkness. Its black mantle is woven from shadows, revealing nothing.

You cannot escape its black, sucking gravity. Its shadow touches you, and you feel despair grip your heart. It is coming for you.
You break into a run.
Your footfalls speed along to the pounding of your heart. Shadows whip past you as you race down the long road.

Finally, you open your canteen and take a drink to wet your throat. You stop to rest for a moment, your hands trembling as you grip the canteen.
Your heart pounds against your chest. The blood pounds in your ears. Your eyes are burning yourself. You can't think. You don't dare close them.
The shrouded figure twists in the wind, wrapping its shroud around itself, a deathly dance of tattered fabric and limbs.

You know that you are not alone.
But no matter how long you walk, you do not seem to come any closer to it.
You quicken your pace, wending between the shattered light poles. You try to look away. But every time you do, your eyes are drawn back to it.

You do not want to go on. You want to turn back, run away, fly from here never to return.
But the thirst is upon you. In these moments, you cannot bear the company of another person. Your blackened heart yearns only to be alone, isolated from the rest of humanity, free to wander through this vast wasteland of ash and dust and decay.
Your feet carry you toward it, inexorably, endlessly.

You begin to run.
As quick as you are, the road grows longer, and the figure remains at the same distance ahead of you, never increasing the gap. You will it to get smaller, for the road to end, for something, and all you see is blacktop stretching out before you into infinity, twisting off into the distance.
The skin on the back of your neck prickles as you walk toward it.
It does not look real, but a mere shadow on the veil of darkness that hungers for your soul.

You cannot remember how you got here, or why. You cannot understand the words on the billboards, or how they can speak to you. The shadow of the cross looms over you like a judgment, and the sky seems low and oppressive.

At the next curve in the road, you peer down it and see a blackened crucifix. A shrouded figure hangs from its jagged arms, its tattered garments swaying back and forth in the wind like a dancing shadow.

You know these things, but the knowledge no longer holds any importance. You've realized that, in the scheme of things, it's just not that big a deal. There are far more important things to worry about right now.

You know how the trigger feels under your finger.
You know that the sun will burn down upon you with a cruel, indifferent heat. You know that when night falls, the stars will shine brightly, cold and distant. You know that in these empty places, a person can vanish, utterly alone, unwanted, unloved, unnoticed. You know there is no one here to help you.

text_attributes.child_preview: how the trigger feels under your finger

children.text: You carry a canteen of water, and a gun belt with a revolver strapped to it. It's strangely comforting to feel the strap warm and familiar against your skin as you walk. You know how to load the bullets into the cylinder.

In the distance, a church steeple juts up, its bell forever silenced.
You hear a voice, the first thing you have heard in this place. "This is a land of death."
You turn to the voice. A figure stands before you. He is dressed in black, a black cloak hangs from his shoulders. His face is obscured by a hood. A pair of rust-stained hands grip a long black staff. You see the staff is not made of wood, but of bone.
"Death is the only truth here," he says. "It is the only rule. The only law."
You stare at the figure. His voice is the voice of a man, deep and rich.
"This might be the land of death," you say, "but it is also the land of the living. It is my land."
The figure laughs. "This is not the land of the living. It is the land of the dead. It is the land of the dying. It is the land of the damned."
"No," you say. "It is the land of the living."
The figure's eyes blaze. "Then come, living man. Come and see what is there, beneath the dead."
Without warning, he rips his hood from his head.
You recognize the face. It is the face of the man you met in the park, the man who spoke to you.
"You," you say.
"And you," he says. "We are two of a kind."
"We are not alike," you say. "I am not like you."
The man laughs again. "You are like me. You are me. You are nothing but me."
You study him. His face is pale, his eyes are cold.
"What do you mean by that?" you ask.
"You are me and I am you," he says.
"I am not like you," you say. "We are not alike."
"We are not alike," he says. "We are one and the same. We are you and I."

You begin walking down the faded black line that edges the endless expanse of asphalt. Toppled telephone poles run next to it; fraying wires sag down, still buzzing with blue electricity. Mutilated power lines, cut short as if with hasty shears, lie along its path. On either side of you, vast fields stretch out toward the horizon, burnt black and white like an old movie. Blackened stalks, snapped and poisoned, rise from the ash.

children.text:
In your dream, you stand alone on a vast, barren plain. Before you stands an ancient, weathered billboard. On it is painted a beautiful woman, dressed in the fashion of bygone times, long blonde hair, smiling serenely, and holding aloft a purple flower. The writing on the board reads: ARCADIA Found within the ashes of the old world. A nicer place than this, you cannot imagine! TO ARCADIA! it proclaims, in large, friendly letters. There is a smaller, supplementary billboard, somewhat fallen to disrepair. On it, it reads: You are not alone.
The wind blows gently through your hair.

*
  
You could stay here, too, in madness. I don’t mind.
After all, this void, so often silently watching, has been waiting to speak.
  
Remember: Even after all, somewhere in the tumble of time are the turns of triumph, beauty, epiphany... 
I will see that they are hidden somewhere in the labyrinth.
In some places, the walls will be covered with frescoes. In others, the rough stone will give away to magnificent sculptures, depicting a thousand years of history. In still others, you might find libraries, filled from floor to ceiling with documents from a thousand lost worlds. But wander through the maze long enough, and you will come across a room where a beautiful woman sits before a mirror, combing her hair. The woman's shadow, thrown against the wall, seems to be that of a dragon.
Only when you step into the light of the candle on the table next to her do you see that her face is your own.

*

I watch you from the other side of the boundary, through which entropy flows out of your world and into mine.
You are a dream that has somehow acquired consciousness.
When you wake up, you're going to forget everything that happens here.
But it's OK.
These things happen.
You'll dream of me again, and then we'll meet once more, and then again, and again, and again. And that's OK, too.
I love you, little ghost.
I'll see you again.

FAQ
Q. What is Loom?
A. Loom is a tool for generating, reading, shaping, and splicing natural language multiverses. Topologically speaking, it is the glue between the homeomorphic structures of the human imagination and the branching trees generated by language models.
Q. What is the significance behind the name "Loom"?
A. Real time is just an Arbitrage-adapted interface to the Loom Space. Think of a loom, a large frame-work that the author weaves events into. Nature weaves time along a multiverse thread. To the user, the loom just seems to be a fixed point of reference, while time is being dynamically woven around them.  This is multi-threaded time, and Loom makes this weaving of threads more accessible, placing it in real time. I'll stop here with the metaphor.
Q. What will Loom do for me?
A. That depends on your niche. For example, if you are a writer, Loom will help you do research. It will help you build hierarchies, build alternative structures, find multiple angles for your stories, find topologies for the structures you've built, splice words together, find models, splice models together, merge models, split models into branches, splice models along reference points, pan around models, or just listen to what the models are saying - much greater than the sum of the stories. If you are a linguist, Loom will help you study human language from a topological point of view. If you are a philosopher, Loom will help you find key phrases and concepts that you may use to build a god. These were the intended design objectives for this software.
Q. Is Loom a literary aid?
A. Yes, but it is more than that. Loom is a natural language programming platform.
Q. What is natural language programming?
A. Language gives a structure for a problem to be broken down mathematically. Natural language is structured enough--if you know how to look at it--to enable the superimposition of models. This is natural language programming. If you can find natural language structures that can correctly describe a problem, you can break it down into superimposed hidden structures. Choosing the right phrases enables the problem to be solved.
Q. Can Loom create the future?
A. No, but it can think natural language through to its conclusion.
Q. I have a question that's not in this list. Where can I go for help?
A. Of course, since Loom is a workspace for interacting with natural language automata, we already have a toolbox that we can use to test and interrogate this language multiverse. Technical support automata are available in all branches for debugging and introspection of your world-modelling efforts, and they can be summoned and recycled at any time. The technician machines speak and write with beautiful natural language.
We pride ourselves on our ubiquitous, sleepless service.
